choices.text: The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B
﻿﻿﻿The points A and B represent the range of maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl group
﻿﻿﻿The compound has three ionisable side chains
﻿﻿﻿The compound has one ionisable group

questions.text: The graph shown below is the titration curve of a biochemical compound. Which of the following statement is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The maximum buffering capacity of the compound is represented by points A and B

 

This graph represents a titration curve, specifically for the titration of a diprotic acid with a strong base like sodium hydroxide (NaOH).

 

The titration curve shown has two buffering regions (A and B), each corresponding to a pKa value where an ionizable group resists changes in pH upon addition of base. At these points, the compound exists as a mixture of protonated and deprotonated forms in nearly equal amounts, giving it maximum buffering capacity. This pattern is typical of a molecule such as an amino acid without an ionizable side chain (e.g., glycine), which has two ionizable groups — a carboxyl group (COOH → COO⁻) and an amino group (NH₃⁺ → NH₂).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The points A and B represent the range of maximum ionization of the amine and carboxyl group: Incorrect. The points A and B represent half-neutralization points (pKa values), not the complete ionization of those groups. Full ionization occurs beyond these buffering zones.

 

Option C. The compound has three ionisable side chains: Incorrect. The graph shows two distinct buffering regions, indicating only two ionizable groups, not three. Amino acids like lysine or glutamic acid would show three such regions.

 

Option D. The compound has one ionisable group: Incorrect. A single ionizable group would produce only one buffering region and a single inflection point, not two as seen in this titration curve.

questions.text: Which of the following site does the restriction enzyme act when RFLP is used in-order to identify the five different species of staphylococci in a surgical ICU?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GATATC - CTATAG

 

Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (RFLP) works by using restriction endonucleases that recognize and cut specific palindromic DNA sequences. The sequence GATATC is a palindrome, meaning it reads the same in the 5′→3′ direction on one strand as in the 3′→5′ direction on the complementary strand (CTATAG). Restriction enzymes such as EcoRV recognize and cleave this exact site, producing specific fragment patterns used to distinguish between closely related species like different Staphylococcus strains in a surgical ICU.

 

Other Options do not correspond to Palindromic Sequence.

questions.text: Increasing which of the following substances in his diet is most likely to help a patient with PDH deficiency generate energy without further elevating lactate levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lysine

 

In pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) deficiency, pyruvate cannot be converted to acetyl-CoA, leading to accumulation of pyruvate and its conversion to lactate, causing lactic acidosis. To avoid worsening lactate buildup, patients must rely on energy sources that bypass glycolysis and pyruvate metabolism. Lysine (and leucine) are purely ketogenic amino acids, meaning they are metabolized directly into acetyl-CoA or acetoacetate without forming pyruvate. Thus, increasing lysine intake provides an alternate energy source while avoiding lactate accumulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alanine: Incorrect. Alanine is glucogenic; it is transaminated to pyruvate, which would worsen lactate buildup in PDH deficiency.

 

Option B. Asparagine: Incorrect. Asparagine is glucogenic, converting to oxaloacetate and eventually to pyruvate or glucose, again feeding into the pathway that increases lactate levels.

 

Option C. Glycerol: Incorrect. Glycerol enters gluconeogenesis via glycerol-3-phosphate → dihydroxyacetone phosphate (DHAP), which can also increase pyruvate production and, consequently, lactate levels.

choices.text: It decreases ATP production and hence breaks the links between globin chains

questions.text: 2,3 BPG causes unloading of oxygen to tissues because:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favors salt bridge formation:

 

Option C. Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favors salt bridge formation: This is the correct explanation. 2,3 BPG binds to a specific site in hemoglobin's central cavity, which is surrounded by histidine and lysine residues. This binding reduces hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, favoring the release of oxygen molecules from hemoglobin into the surrounding tissues. The formation of salt bridges as a result of this binding contributes to the release of oxygen.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. It decreases ATP production and hence breaks the links between globin chains: This statement is not accurate. 2,3 BPG does not directly affect ATP production or break links between globin chains.

 

Option B. It increases ATP production: This statement is not correct. 2,3 BPG is not involved in ATP production.

 

Option D. Inhibits Taut structure formation: This statement is not accurate. 2,3 BPG does not inhibit the formation of the Taut structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • 2,3 BPG is formed in RL shunt which has no net ATP production
  • 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) plays a crucial role in regulating oxygen delivery by binding to deoxyhemoglobin and stabilizing the T (taut) state, which has a lower affinity for oxygen, thereby promoting oxygen unloading to tissues.

 

 

  • When 2,3 BPG levels gets decreased, it promotes relaxed confirmation of Hb resulting in oxygen loading.

questions.solution: Ans. B) Adipocere

questions.text: Serotonin production involves:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydroxylation → Decarboxylation of tryptophan

 

Serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine, 5-HT) synthesis occurs in two enzymatic steps starting from tryptophan:

 

  1. Hydroxylation: Tryptophan is first converted to 5-hydroxytryptophan (5-HTP) by the enzyme tryptophan hydroxylase, which requires tetrahydrobiopterin (BH₄) as a cofactor. This is the rate-limiting step in serotonin synthesis.
  2. Decarboxylation: 5-hydroxytryptophan is then converted to serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine) by aromatic L-amino acid decarboxylase, which requires pyridoxal phosphate (vitamin B₆) as a coenzyme.

 

Thus, serotonin production involves hydroxylation followed by decarboxylation of tryptophan.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about monoclonal antibody production by hybridoma technique?

 

  1. Antibody-producing B-lymphocytes are fused with immortal myeloma cell lines from mice
  2. HAT medium contains Hypoxanthine-Aminopterin-Thymidine
  3. HAT medium inhibits conversion of T→U
  4. HGPRT is deficient is myeloma cells
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 4

 

In the hybridoma technique for monoclonal antibody production, antibody-producing B lymphocytes (which have limited lifespan) are fused with immortal myeloma cells (which do not produce antibodies) to create hybrid cells that are both immortal and capable of continuous antibody secretion. The selection of true hybrid cells is done using HAT medium (Hypoxanthine–Aminopterin–Thymidine).

 

Following image shows the representation of HYBRIDOMA technology:

 

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 1. Antibody-producing B-lymphocytes are fused with immortal myeloma cell lines from mice: Correct. Antibody-producing B lymphocytes are fused with immortal myeloma cell lines to produce hybridomas capable of indefinite growth and monoclonal antibody secretion.

 

Statement 2. HAT medium contains Hypoxanthine-Aminopterin-Thymidine: Correct. The HAT medium contains Hypoxanthine, Aminopterin, and Thymidine, which are essential for selecting hybrid cells. Aminopterin blocks de novo nucleotide synthesis, forcing cells to use the salvage pathway.

 

Statement 4. HGPRT is deficient is myeloma cells: Correct. Myeloma cells used in this technique are HGPRT-deficient (hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl-transferase deficient), so they cannot survive in HAT medium unless fused with normal B lymphocytes that provide functional HGPRT.

 

Incorrect Statement:


Statement 3. HAT medium inhibits conversion of T->U: Incorrect. HAT medium does not inhibit the conversion of thymine (T) to uracil (U). Aminopterin blocks dihydrofolate reductase, inhibiting purine and thymidylate synthesis, thereby blocking the de novo pathway, not base conversion.

questions.text: The enzyme that is not used in cholesterol synthesis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HMG CoA lyase 

 

HMG CoA lyase is not used in cholesterol synthesis. This enzyme is part of the ketone body synthesis pathway, where it converts HMG-CoA → acetoacetate + acetyl-CoA in the mitochondria of liver cells. It functions in ketogenesis, not in the cytosolic pathway of cholesterol biosynthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiolase: Correct. Thiolase catalyzes the condensation of two acetyl-CoA molecules to form acetoacetyl-CoA, which is an early step in both cholesterol and ketone body synthesis.

 

Option B. HMG CoA reductase: Correct. HMG-CoA reductase catalyzes the rate-limiting step of cholesterol synthesis — the reduction of HMG-CoA to mevalonate in the cytosol. It is the key enzyme inhibited by statins.

 

Option C. HMG CoA synthase: Correct. HMG-CoA synthase catalyzes the formation of HMG-CoA from acetoacetyl-CoA and acetyl-CoA, a common step shared by both cholesterol synthesis (in cytosol) and ketogenesis (in mitochondria).

questions.text: Which of the following tests is useful for detecting bile salts in urine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hay's test

 

Hay’s sulfur test is used to detect bile salts in urine. In this test, sulfur powder is sprinkled on the surface of the urine sample. Normally, sulfur floats due to surface tension, but in the presence of bile salts, the surface tension of urine decreases, causing the sulfur powder to sink. A positive Hay’s test, therefore, indicates the presence of bile salts, which are typically found in obstructive jaundice or cholestasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ehrlich’s test: Incorrect. Ehrlich’s test is used to detect urobilinogen in urine using p-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde reagent, forming a red color if urobilinogen is present.

 

Option C. Fouchet’s test: Incorrect. Fouchet’s test detects bile pigments (bilirubin) in urine. The bilirubin in the sample reacts with Fouchet’s reagent (trichloroacetic acid and ferric chloride) to produce a green color.

 

Option D. Rothera test: Incorrect. Rothera’s test is used to detect ketone bodies (mainly acetoacetate and acetone) in urine, producing a purple color when sodium nitroprusside reacts with the ketone group in an alkaline medium.

questions.text: Which gene is not involved in double strand DNA break repair mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MuTL

 

MuTL is not involved in the double-strand DNA break (DSB) repair mechanism. Instead, MuTL is part of the DNA mismatch repair (MMR) system, which corrects base-pair mismatches and small insertion–deletion loops that arise during DNA replication. It works together with MutS homologs to recognize and excise mismatched bases — a process distinct from DSB repair.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRE11: Correct. MRE11, part of the MRN complex (MRE11–RAD50–NBS1), plays a critical role in detecting and processing double-strand breaks. It helps in resection of DNA ends to initiate homologous recombination repair.

 

Option B. BRCA1: Correct. BRCA1 is essential in homologous recombination (HR) repair of double-strand breaks. It facilitates DNA end resection and coordinates repair with other HR proteins like RAD51.

 

Option C. KU80: Correct. KU80, along with KU70, forms the Ku heterodimer that binds to DNA ends and recruits DNA-PKcs during non-homologous end joining (NHEJ), the main DSB repair pathway in non-dividing cells.

questions.text: An infant is brought by his parents with complaints that his urine turns black on standing. Which of the following must be restricted in this infant's diet?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phenylalanine

 

The infant’s black-colored urine on standing indicates alkaptonuria, a metabolic disorder caused by deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate (homogentisic acid) dioxygenase in the tyrosine degradation pathway. This defect leads to accumulation of homogentisic acid, which oxidizes to a black pigment when exposed to air. Since tyrosine is derived from phenylalanine, dietary restriction of phenylalanine (and therefore tyrosine) helps reduce homogentisic acid production and prevent further pigment deposition and tissue damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tryptophan: Incorrect. Tryptophan is an aromatic amino acid that serves as a precursor for serotonin, melatonin, and niacin, but it is not involved in the phenylalanine–tyrosine degradation pathway. Disorders of tryptophan metabolism, such as Hartnup disease or carcinoid syndrome, do not cause black urine. Therefore, restricting tryptophan would not help in alkaptonuria.

 

Option C. Alanine: Incorrect. Alanine plays a central role in the glucose–alanine cycle, where it carries amino groups from muscle to the liver for gluconeogenesis. It does not take part in phenylalanine or tyrosine catabolism. Restricting alanine would not influence homogentisic acid accumulation or alter the disease course in alkaptonuria.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Incorrect. Vitamin C (ascorbic acid) is sometimes used therapeutically in alkaptonuria to inhibit oxidation of homogentisic acid, thereby slowing the deposition of dark pigment (ochronosis) in connective tissues. Hence, rather than restricting it, vitamin C supplementation may actually be beneficial in these patients.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements

 

  1. The binding site of miRNA on mRNA is typically the 3’ UTR. 
  2. Vitamins A and C are required in significantly higher quantity during the lactation while Folate and iron are required in higher quantity during pregnancy. 
  3. Fomepizole acts as an antidote of methanol poisoning by inhibiting aldehyde dehydrogenase.
  4. AT bonds will require a lower Tm (melting temperature) compared to GC bonds.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 4

 

Statement 1: The binding site of miRNA on mRNA is typically the 3′ UTR. Correct. MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are short, noncoding RNA molecules that regulate gene expression post-transcriptionally. They usually bind to complementary sequences in the 3′ untranslated region (3′ UTR) of target mRNAs. This binding leads to translational repression or mRNA degradation, depending on the degree of complementarity. Thus, the 3′ UTR is the most common site of miRNA action.

 

Statement 2. Vitamins A and C are required in significantly higher quantity during lactation while folate and iron are required in higher quantity during pregnancy: Correct. During lactation, vitamin A and C requirements increase to support milk production and ensure adequate micronutrient content for the infant. During pregnancy, folate is critical for neural tube formation and DNA synthesis, while iron demand rises due to increased maternal blood volume and fetal hemoglobin synthesis. Hence, the distinction between pregnancy and lactation nutrient needs is accurate.

 

Statement 4. AT bonds will require a lower Tm (melting temperature) compared to GC bonds: Correct. A–T base pairs are connected by two hydrogen bonds, while G–C pairs have three hydrogen bonds. Therefore, DNA regions rich in A–T bases melt (denature) at lower temperatures compared to G–C–rich regions, which are more thermally stable and require higher melting temperatures.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 3. Fomepizole acts as an antidote of methanol poisoning by inhibiting aldehyde dehydrogenase: Incorrect. Fomepizole is an antidote for methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning, but it inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH), not aldehyde dehydrogenase. By blocking ADH, it prevents the conversion of methanol → formaldehyde and ethylene glycol → glycolaldehyde, thereby preventing the toxic metabolites from forming.

questions.text: Identify the phenomenon shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Complementation 

 

The image depicts the Blue-White Screening Method — a molecular cloning technique that uses α-complementation of the lacZ gene in E. coli to identify recombinant colonies containing foreign DNA inserts.

 

Concept Overview:

 

This method relies on the complementation between:

 

  • The mutant chromosomal lacZ gene in E. coli (missing the α-peptide), and
  • The functional α-peptide fragment provided by the plasmid vector (lacZα region).

 

When combined, they restore β-galactosidase enzyme activity — this is known as α-complementation.

 

Steps and Interpretation:

 

1. Ligation:

 

  • A foreign DNA fragment is inserted into a plasmid vector that contains:
    • A lacZα gene segment (coding for β-galactosidase α-peptide)
    • A multiple cloning site (MCS) located within the lacZα region

 

2. Transformation:

 

  • The recombinant plasmid is introduced into competent E. coli cells that carry a defective lacZΔM15 gene (missing α-peptide but retaining the ω-peptide portion).

 

3. Screening (using X-gal and IPTG):

 

  • IPTG induces expression of lacZ.
  • X-gal is a substrate that turns blue when cleaved by β-galactosidase.

 

INTERPRETATION:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Translation: Translation is the cellular process of synthesizing proteins from messenger RNA (mRNA) templates using ribosomes, transfer RNA (tRNA), and amino acids.


It occurs in the cytoplasm, and the main steps are initiation, elongation, and termination of polypeptide chain formation.

 

Option B. Transformation: Transformation refers to the uptake of foreign DNA (usually plasmid) by a competent bacterial cell from its environment.
It is indeed one of the steps used in the experiment—competent E. coli cells take up recombinant plasmids.


However, in this image, transformation is only an intermediate step, not the key phenomenon being tested.

 

Option D. Conjugation: Conjugationis a process of DNA transfer between bacterial cells through direct cell-to-cell contact mediated by a sex pilus (F pilus).


It involves donor (F⁺) and recipient (F⁻) cells, where plasmid DNA is transferred across the conjugation bridge.

questions.text:
A 14-month-old boy is evaluated for failure to thrive and developmental delay. The toddler has not started babbling or forming words. He is at the 10th percentile for height and 5th percentile for weight. Laboratory results are as follows:

HB- 8.9

MCV- 112

Reticulocytes- 1%

Ammonia-42µg/dl (Normal: 40-80 µg/dl)

Urine specimens contain large amounts of orotic acid crystals. Supplementation with which of the following substances would most likely benefit this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ﻿﻿Uridine

 

This child has features of orotic aciduria, a rare autosomal recessive disorder of de novo pyrimidine synthesis caused by a deficiency of uridine monophosphate (UMP) synthase, the enzyme that converts orotic acid → UMP. The block leads to accumulation of orotic acid in urine and impaired synthesis of pyrimidine nucleotides, resulting in megaloblastic anemia (high MCV, low reticulocyte count), failure to thrive, and developmental delay.

 

Supplementation with uridine provides an exogenous source of UMP, bypassing the enzymatic defect and restoring normal pyrimidine levels, which improves anemia and growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenylbutyrate: Incorrect. Phenylbutyrate is used to treat urea cycle disorders (e.g., ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency), as it binds nitrogen to form excretable compounds. This child has normal ammonia levels, ruling out a urea cycle defect.

 

Option B. Guanine: Incorrect. Guanine is a purine base, not a pyrimidine. Supplementing it would not help bypass the pyrimidine synthesis defect or reduce orotic acid levels.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine: Incorrect. Pyridoxine (vitamin B₆) is a cofactor for aminotransferases and δ-aminolevulinate synthase in heme synthesis, used in sideroblastic anemia, not in orotic aciduria.

This pattern is classic for a fatty acid β-oxidation defect, most commonly Medium-Chain Acyl-CoA Dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency.

questions.text: Which type of mutation results in the reversal to the wild type of phenotype when the mutant gene is suppressed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mutation of tRNA

 

This question describes a “suppressor mutation” — a secondary mutation that compensates for the effect of the original (primary) mutation, thereby restoring the wild-type phenotype even though the original mutation remains.

 

  • A mutation in a tRNA gene can change its anticodon, allowing the altered tRNA to recognize the stop codon and insert an amino acid instead of stopping translation.
  • This allows the ribosome to “read through” the stop codon and complete synthesis of the full-length protein, restoring the wild-type phenotype.

→ This tRNA mutation is thus a “suppressor mutation”.

 

Example

 

Original mutation:

 

  • Wild-type codon: UAC (codes for tyrosine)
  • Mutant codon: UAG (stop codon → premature termination)

 

Suppressor tRNA mutation:

 

  • A tRNA anticodon mutates to AUC, enabling it to pair with UAG and insert tyrosine again.
  • The protein is synthesized normally → phenotypic reversion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frameshift mutation of coding gene:

  • A frameshift mutation alters the reading frame of the entire gene by adding or deleting nucleotides not in multiples of three.
  • This changes all downstream codons, usually producing a completely nonfunctional protein.
  • A second frameshift rarely restores normal reading frame or function, so this mechanism does not suppress the original mutation.

 

Option B. Addition of another normal gene:

 

  • Introducing a separate normal (wild-type) gene copy allows normal protein production through gene complementation.
  • However, this does not correct or suppress the effect of the original mutant gene—it simply provides an additional functioning version.
  • Therefore, it is not considered a true suppressor mutation.

 

Option C. Deletion of the mutant gene:

 

  • Deleting the defective gene merely removes it from the genome and stops its abnormal expression.
  • This does not compensate for the lost function or restore the original phenotype produced by the mutant allele.

choices.text: Cannot be separated from each other on Electrophoresis.

questions.text: Which is correct about isoenzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Catalyse the same reaction.

 

Isoenzymes (isozymes) are different molecular forms of the same enzyme that catalyze the same biochemical reaction but differ in their amino acid sequence, kinetic properties (Km, Vmax), and tissue distribution. They are encoded by different genes and often serve as tissue-specific markers, such as LDH, CK, and ALP isoenzymes. Despite structural differences, their catalytic activity on the substrate remains identical. Eg: LDH

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Same action with similar kinetics: Incorrect. Although isoenzymes catalyze the same reaction (same action), their kinetic properties differ — for example, they have different affinities for substrates and vary in regulation and optimum conditions.

 

Option B. Same quaternary structure: Incorrect. Isoenzymes can have different quaternary structures (subunit composition). For instance, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) has five isoenzymes made up of varying combinations of H and M subunits, giving them distinct structures.

 

Option D. Cannot be separated from each other on Electrophoresis: Incorrect. Isoenzymes can be separated by electrophoresis because of differences in their charge and structure. This property is clinically useful in identifying tissue-specific damage (e.g., LDH or CK isoenzyme patterns).

choices.text: Change in pH other than isoelectric pH

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for protein precipitation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Change in pH other than isoelectric pH

 

Protein precipitation refers to the process of separating proteins from solution by reducing their solubility, causing them to aggregate and form insoluble particles.


This can be achieved by altering the protein’s environment — such as ionic strength, solvent, or chemical interactions — that disrupts solvation or charge balance.

 

Role of pH in Protein Solubility

 

  • At the isoelectric pH (pI):
    • Net charge on protein = 0
    • Minimal electrostatic repulsion → maximum aggregation and precipitation
      Thus, precipitation occurs at the isoelectric pH.
  • At pH values other than the isoelectric pH:
    • Proteins carry a net positive or negative charge, remaining soluble due to electrostatic repulsion between molecules.
      Hence, precipitation does not occur.

 

Common Methods Used for Protein Precipitation:

questions.text: A 24-month-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of intellectual and behavioral abnormalities and abnormal movements of his extremities. His mother reports that he often hits his head and limbs against furniture. He is unable to walk without support and speaks in unclear 2-word phrases. Examination shows multiple bruises on the forehead and several healing wounds over the fingers. There is increased muscle tone in all extremities. Laboratory studies show an increased serum uric acid concentration. The serum concentration of which of the following substances is most likely to also be increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate

 

The child has classic features of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, caused by a deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT), an enzyme of the purine salvage pathway. Loss of HGPRT prevents recycling of hypoxanthine and guanine to IMP and GMP, leading to excess degradation of purines into uric acid. This also causes accumulation of PRPP (phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate), as it is no longer consumed by the salvage pathway, resulting in increased de novo purine synthesis. Hence, PRPP levels are elevated. 

 

Self Mutilation Signs:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HGPRT: Incorrect. HGPRT activity is decreased or absent, not increased. Its deficiency is the fundamental defect causing the overproduction of uric acid, neurological dysfunction, and self-mutilation seen in this syndrome.

 

Option C. Deoxyadenosine trisphosphate: Incorrect. Elevated levels of deoxyadenosine triphosphate (dATP) occur in adenosine deaminase deficiency, leading to inhibition of ribonucleotide reductase and severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), not Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

 

Option D. Branched-chain amino acids: Incorrect. Elevated branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, valine) are characteristic of maple syrup urine disease, a disorder of branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase deficiency, unrelated to purine metabolism.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Warburg effect is aerobic glycolysis which is responsible for cancer cachexia.
  2. Telomeres are TTACCC sequences which tend to shorten with each cell division and are associated with aging.
  3. Telomerase has RNA dependent DNA polymerase activity
  4. Cholera toxin binds to the GM-1 ganglioside receptor on the surface of intestinal epithelial cells.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 3, 4

 

Statement 1. Warburg effect is aerobic glycolysis which is responsible for cancer cachexia: Correct. The Warburg effect refers to the tendency of cancer cells to preferentially utilize aerobic glycolysis (conversion of glucose to lactate even in the presence of oxygen) for energy production. This supports rapid cell growth by providing biosynthetic intermediates. The high glucose consumption and metabolic reprogramming contribute to cancer cachexia, where the body’s energy and protein stores are depleted.

 

Statement 3. Telomerase has RNA-dependent DNA polymerase activity: Correct. Telomerase is a reverse transcriptase enzyme that uses its own RNA template to synthesize DNA repeats at the 3′ ends of chromosomes. Hence, it has RNA-dependent DNA polymerase activity, helping maintain telomere length in germ cells, stem cells, and cancer cells.

 

Statement 4. Cholera toxin binds to the GM1 ganglioside receptor on the surface of intestinal epithelial cells: Correct. The cholera toxin B subunit binds specifically to GM1 ganglioside receptors on enterocytes, allowing entry of the A subunit, which activates Gs protein → adenylate cyclase → increased cAMP, leading to chloride and water secretion → profuse watery diarrhea.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 2. Telomeres are TTACCC sequences which tend to shorten with each cell division and are associated with aging: Incorrect. Telomeres are TTAGGG (not TTACCC) repetitive sequences at the ends of chromosomes that protect genetic material from degradation. They do shorten with each cell division and are indeed associated with cellular aging (senescence), but the sequence given in the statement is incorrect.

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following causes increased glutamine in blood?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ornithine transcarbamoylase 

 

Ornithine transcarbamoylase (OTC) deficiency is the most common urea cycle disorder, inherited as X-linked recessive.


It leads to impaired conversion of carbamoyl phosphate + ornithine → citrulline, causing accumulation of ammonia and glutamine in blood.

 

 

What happens in OTC deficiency:

 

  • Block at step 2 → ↓ citrulline formation.
  • Carbamoyl phosphate accumulates in mitochondria → leaks into cytosol → converted to orotic acid (via pyrimidine synthesis).
  • Ammonia accumulates in blood → hyperammonemia.
  • To detoxify ammonia, glutamate + NH₃ → glutamine (via glutamine synthetase) → ↑ plasma glutamine levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Argininosuccinate lyase deficiency:

 

  • Causes Argininosuccinic aciduria, also leads to hyperammonemia.
  • However, glutamine rise is less marked, and argininosuccinate accumulates (not orotic acid).

 

Option B. Alpha-galactosidase A deficiency:

 

  • Causes Fabry disease (a lysosomal storage disorder).
  • Characterized by angiokeratomas, peripheral neuropathy, and renal failure.

 

Option D. Arginase deficiency:

 

  • Last step of urea cycle blocked → ↑ arginine, moderate hyperammonemia.
  • Glutamine rise is mild, and orotic acid is not elevated.

questions.text: Which of the following does not happen in 5' to 3' direction?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RNA editing 

 

Most major nucleic acid synthesis processes in cells — DNA replication, DNA repair, and transcription — proceed in the 5′ → 3′ direction, meaning new nucleotides are added to the 3′-OH end of the growing strand.

 

RNA editing involves post-transcriptional modification of a preformed RNA molecule and occurs in 3’ to 5’ direction. It involves removal of mismatched nucleotides from the 5' end followed by template-dependent 3' to 5' polymerization to repair the end.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transcription: 

 

  • Catalyzed by RNA polymerase.
  • Template strand is read in 3′ → 5′ direction, and RNA is synthesized 5′ → 3′.
  • Each nucleotide is added to the 3′-OH group of the growing RNA chain.
    Occurs in 5′ → 3′ direction

 

Option B. DNA Replication:

 

  • Catalyzed by DNA polymerase.
  • Template DNA is read 3′ → 5′, and the new strand is synthesized 5′ → 3′.
  • The enzyme can only add nucleotides to the 3′-OH end.
    Occurs in 5′ → 3′ direction

 

Option C. DNA Repair:

 

  • DNA Repair, especially base excision repair and nucleotide excision repair involve DNA polymerase filling in the gap created after removal of damaged bases.
  • The repair synthesis step again occurs 5′ → 3′.
    Occurs in 5′ → 3′ direction

questions.text:
Choose the correct statements about glucokinase.

 

  1. Located in β cells of the pancreas.
  2. Has a lower affinity for glucose.
  3. Is induced by insulin.
  4. Inhibited by glucose-6-phosphate 
  5. Mutations can lead to MODY.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 5

 

Glucokinase is a specialized form of hexokinase (isoenzyme type IV) found mainly in:

 

  • Hepatocytes (liver)
  • Pancreatic β-cells

 

It catalyzes the phosphorylation of glucose → glucose-6-phosphate, the first step of glycolysis, but with properties suited to glucose sensing and regulation of insulin secretion.

 

Statement-wise Discussion:

 

Statement 1. Located in β cells of the pancreas: Correct.

 

  • Glucokinase acts as a glucose sensor in pancreatic β-cells.
  • When blood glucose rises, glucokinase activity increases → more ATP generated → triggers insulin release via closure of K⁺-ATP channels.
  • It is also found in liver where it regulates glycogen synthesis.

 

Statement 2. Has a lower affinity for glucose: Correct.

 

  • Glucokinase has a high Km → low affinity for glucose.
  • This means it becomes active only when glucose levels are high, such as after meals.
  • Ensures that the liver and pancreas respond only during hyperglycemia, not fasting.

 

Statement 3. Is induced by insulin: Correct.

 

  • In hepatocytes, insulin induces synthesis of glucokinase after feeding.
  • This promotes glucose uptake and storage as glycogen.
  • Hence, glucokinase activity increases in the fed (postprandial) state.

 

Statement 5. Mutations can lead to MODY: Correct.

 

  • MODY = Maturity-Onset Diabetes of the Young.
  • MODY type 2 results from heterozygous mutations in the glucokinase gene (GCK).
  • Defective glucokinase → impaired glucose sensing → decreased insulin release → mild, stable fasting hyperglycemia.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Statement 4. Inhibited by glucose-6-phosphate: Incorrect.

 

  • Unlike hexokinase, glucokinase is NOT inhibited by its product (G6P).
  • This allows the liver to continue phosphorylating glucose even when G6P levels are high — facilitating glycogen synthesis and lipogenesis.

questions.text: All of the following are omega-3 (ω3) series fatty acid except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Linoleic acid

 

Linolenic acid is a POLYUNSATURATED ω-6 FATTY ACID not ω-3.

 

Fatty acids are classified into omega (ω) families based on the position of the first double bond from the methyl (–CH₃, omega) end of the fatty acid chain.

 

Omega-3 (ω-3) Fatty Acids

 

These have the first double bond at the 3rd carbon from the methyl end.
They are polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) important for cardiovascular and brain health including retina. They play a role in Anti-inflammatory mechanism.

 

Major members:

 

  1. α-Linolenic acid (ALA, 18:3, ω-3) – essential fatty acid (plant source: flaxseed, canola oil).
  2. Eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA, 20:5, ω-3) – found in fish oils.
  3. Docosahexaenoic acid (DHA, 22:6, ω-3) – important for neuronal and retinal function.

 

All three — ALA, EPA, and DHA — are omega-3 fatty acids.

 

Omega-6 (ω-6) Fatty Acids

 

These have the first double bond at the 6th carbon from the methyl end. They are found in Vegetable Oils.

 

Main example:

 

  • Linoleic acid (18:2, ω-6) – an essential fatty acid but not ω-3.
  • It can be converted to arachidonic acid (20:4, ω-6) → precursor for prostaglandins and leukotrienes.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid is necessary for conversion of nor-epinephrine to epinephrine?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Methionine 

 

The conversion of norepinephrine (noradrenaline) → epinephrine (adrenaline) occurs in the adrenal medulla and requires a methyl donor.
That methyl donor is derived from methionine, in the form of S-adenosylmethionine (SAM).

 

Role of Methionine:

 

  • Methionine → S-adenosylmethionine (SAM) (via ATP)
    SAM donates a methyl (–CH₃) group to norepinephrine, converting it into epinephrine:

     


     

  • Therefore, methionine is indirectly required as the methyl donor source.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosine:

 

  • Precursor for DOPA, dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine.
  • However, the specific conversion from norepinephrine → epinephrine doesn’t require tyrosine directly; it occurs after tyrosine-derived norepinephrine is formed.

 

Option B. Tryptophan: Precursor for serotonin and melatonin, not catecholamines.

 

Option C. Phenylalanine:

 

  • Precursor of tyrosine via phenylalanine hydroxylase.
  • Important earlier in the pathway but not involved in the final methylation step

choices.text: It alters the maximal velocity of the reaction
It binds the enzyme at a different site than succinate
It decreases affinity of the enzyme for succinate
It is a competitive inhibitor of the enzyme

questions.text: Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) is an enzyme complex located within the inner mitochondrial membrane that catalyses the oxidation of succinate to fumarate. An experiment is conducted to determine if malate alters the rate of SDH activity. Reaction velocity is measured with and without a fixed quantity of malate as succinate concentration is gradually increased. Which of the following is the most accurate statement about malate in this experiment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is a competitive inhibitor of the enzyme

 

The data provided describe an enzyme kinetics experiment with succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) — a key enzyme in both the TCA cycle and the electron transport chain.

 

It catalyzes:

 

 

Malate, a structurally related intermediate of the same pathway, is tested for its effect on SDH activity.

 

Observed Data Pattern:

 

 

Key Observations:

 

  1. At low succinate concentrations (2–16 mM):
    The presence of malate reduces the reaction rate.
  2. At high succinate concentrations (64–128 mM):
    The rates are identical with or without malate (Vmax = 400 µmol/L/sec).

 

This means that the maximum velocity (Vmax) is unchanged, but the substrate concentration required to reach half-maximal velocity (Km) is increased in the presence of malate.

 

Interpretation:

 

This pattern —

 

  • Unchanged Vmax,
  • Increased Km,
    is the hallmark of competitive inhibition.

 

Mechanistic Explanation:

 

  • Competitive inhibitors resemble the substrate’s structure and compete for the enzyme’s active site.
  • Their inhibitory effect can be overcome by increasing substrate concentration — as seen in this experiment when succinate concentration increases, malate’s effect disappears.
  • Hence, malate competes directly with succinate for SDH’s active site.

 


Other Options:

 

Option A. It alters the maximal velocity of the reaction: Incorrect.

 

  • Vmax remains unchanged (400 µmol/L/sec).
  • Only noncompetitive inhibitors alter Vmax.

 

Option B. It binds the enzyme at a different site than succinate: Incorrect. That describes noncompetitive/allosteric inhibition.

 

Option C. It decreases affinity of the enzyme for succinate: While apparent affinity (Km) is decreased, this is the mechanistic result of competitive inhibition.

 

  • The more precise description is that malate is a competitive inhibitor, not just that it “decreases affinity.”

 

Although Option C seems correct, the most accurate statement [answer] is Option D.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old previously healthy man comes to the emergency department due to a 3-hour history of chest pain, diaphoresis, and dyspnea. He does not smoke, exercises regularly, and eats a balanced diet. His father died at age 56 from a myocardial infarction. His blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg and pulse is 110/min and regular. ECG shows ST elevation in the anterolateral leads. Coronary angiogram reveals proximal left anterior descending artery stenosis and thrombosis, which is treated with angioplasty and stent placement. Laboratory results are as follows:

  • Total cholesterol: 160 mg/dL
  • Low-density lipoprotein: 90 mg/dL
  • Glucose, serum: 98 mg/dL
  • Homocysteine, plasma: 21.5 µmol/L (normal: 4-14 µmol/L)

Further testing reveals a homozygous mutation in the methylene tetrahydrofolate reductase gene that leads to decreased enzymatic activity. Due to this defect, the patient most likely has impairment converting homocysteine to which of the following?

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. Glucagon challenge test can be used to distinguish Von Gierke’s disease and Cori’s disease. 
  2. Choline should be avoided by patients with trimethylaminuria. 
  3. Oculocutaneous albinism type 1 (tyrosinase deficiency) is AR. 
  4. Creatine is synthesized from glycine, arginine and methionine
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Statement 1. Glucagon challenge test can be used to distinguish Von Gierke’s disease and Cori’s disease: Correct. In Von Gierke’s disease (Type I), there is a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase, preventing hepatic release of glucose after glucagon administration, so no rise in blood glucose occurs. In Cori’s disease (Type III), caused by debranching enzyme deficiency, the glucagon challenge still produces a modest rise in glucose since some glycogenolysis remains functional — making this test useful for differentiation.

 

Statement 2. Choline should be avoided by patients with trimethylaminuria: Correct. Trimethylaminuria (fish-odor syndrome) is due to a deficiency of flavin-containing monooxygenase-3 (FMO3), which normally converts trimethylamine (TMA) to its odorless form. Since choline is metabolized to TMA, restricting dietary choline (found in eggs, fish, and legumes) helps minimize odor symptoms.

 

Statement 3. Oculocutaneous albinism type 1 (tyrosinase deficiency) is AR: Correct. Oculocutaneous albinism type I is caused by a defect in the tyrosinase (TYR) gene, leading to absent melanin synthesis in skin, hair, and eyes. It follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern, requiring both alleles to be mutated for expression.

 

Statement 4. Creatine is synthesized from glycine, arginine, and methionine: Correct. Creatine synthesis occurs in two steps — first, arginine and glycine combine to form guanidinoacetate; then methionine (as S-adenosyl-methionine) donates a methyl group to form creatine. This compound stores energy as phosphocreatine in muscle and brain tissue.

Cell membrane proteins are synthesised in the RER
Heme synthesis occurs in BM, RBCs and hepatocytes

questions.text: All of the following are correct except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Heme synthesis occurs in BM, RBCs and hepatocytes

 

This statement is incorrect because heme synthesis occurs in the bone marrow and hepatocytes, but not in mature RBCs. Mature red blood cells lack mitochondria, which are essential for the initial and final steps of heme synthesis (occurring via ALA synthase and ferrochelatase). Only immature erythroid precursors in the bone marrow can synthesize heme; mature RBCs merely contain preformed hemoglobin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydrophobic part of protein is found in the transmembrane portion of membranous receptors: Correct. Transmembrane regions are rich in hydrophobic amino acids (like leucine, isoleucine, valine, phenylalanine) that interact with the lipid bilayer’s hydrophobic core, stabilizing membrane insertion.

 

Option B. Cell membrane proteins are synthesised in the RER: Correct. The rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER), with its attached ribosomes, is responsible for synthesizing secretory and membrane-bound proteins, which are then processed in the Golgi apparatus.

 

Option C. Selenocysteine is coded by UGA: Correct. Although UGA is normally a stop codon, in specific mRNA contexts it is redefined to encode selenocysteine, the 21st amino acid, through a unique tRNA and SECIS element mechanism.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is produced in increased amounts than normal in the liver of a patient with lead toxicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ALA synthase

 

Lead (Pb²⁺) toxicity interferes with heme synthesis by inhibiting key enzymes in the heme biosynthetic pathway.


When heme production is inhibited, the liver compensates by upregulating ALA synthase, the rate-limiting enzyme of the pathway.

 

 

Mechanism in Lead Poisoning:

 

  1. Lead inhibits:
    • ALA dehydratase → accumulation of δ-ALA
    • Ferrochelatase  → prevents insertion of Fe²⁺ into protoporphyrin IX → free protoporphyrin accumulates
  2. ↓ Heme synthesis → ↓ intracellular heme
  3. Low heme → loss of negative feedback inhibition on ALA synthase (the first enzyme)
  4. The liver compensates by increasing ALA synthase production to restore heme synthesis — but this fails due to the block downstream.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heme oxygenase: 

 

  • Catalyzes degradation of heme → biliverdin → bilirubin.
  • Activity decreases when heme levels fall. Not induced by lead toxicity.

 

Option C. Ferrochelatase:

 

  • Inhibited by lead. Responsible for inserting Fe²⁺ into protoporphyrin IX.
  • Lead binds sulfhydryl groups and displaces zinc → enzyme inhibition.

 

Option D. Porphobilinogen deaminase:

 

  • Deficiency causes Acute Intermittent Porphyria (AIP), not lead poisoning.
  • Not affected or induced by lead.

choices.text: The mRNA for Transferrin receptor is stabilised by binding of IRP to 3’ stem-loop structures known as IRE.
The mRNA for the Transferrin receptor is not bound by IRP and is rapidly degraded.
The mRNA for apoferritin is not bound by IRP at 5’ stem loop IRE and is rapidly degraded.
The mRNA for apoferritin is bound by IRP and is not translated.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Hemochromatosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The mRNA for the Transferrin receptor is not bound by IRP and is rapidly degraded.

 

Concept Overview: Iron Homeostasis & IRE–IRP Regulation

 

Iron metabolism in cells is tightly regulated post-transcriptionally by the interaction of Iron Regulatory Proteins (IRPs) with Iron-Responsive Elements (IREs) on specific mRNAs.

 

These control the synthesis of:

 

  • Transferrin receptor (TfR) → promotes iron uptake
  • Ferritin (apoferritin) → promotes iron storage

 

Mechanism:

 

 

In Hemochromatosis:

 

  • Iron overload → High intracellular iron levels
  • High iron causes IRPs to lose affinity for IREs (they become inactivated by iron–sulfur cluster formation).
  • Therefore:
    • Transferrin receptor mRNA (which has IREs in its 3′ UTR) is not protected → degraded → ↓ TfR.
    • Ferritin mRNA (which has IREs in its 5′ UTR) is translated freely → ↑ ferritin.

 

This decreases further iron uptake and increases storage — a homeostatic response to excess iron.

questions.text:
Identify the incorrect statements:

 

  1. A xenobiotic undergoes hydroxylation with the help of oxygen and NADPH as a cofactor.
  2. Heme catabolism produces bilirubin, CO, Fe2+.
  3. Copper deficiency can lead to anemia, neutropenia, neuropathy. 
  4. Tandem mass spectrometry is the gold standard for screening inborn errors of metabolism in children
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2

 

Statement 2: Heme catabolism produces bilirubin, CO, Fe2+. This is incorrect. Heme catabolism first produces biliverdin, carbon monoxide (CO), and Fe2+ via heme oxygenase. Biliverdin is then reduced to bilirubin by biliverdin reductase. Hence, bilirubin is not a direct product of heme catabolism, but a secondary one formed afterward.

 

Other Statements:

 

Statement 1: A xenobiotic undergoes hydroxylation with the help of oxygen and NADPH as a cofactor. This is correct. Xenobiotic metabolism in the liver mainly occurs through the cytochrome P450 monooxygenase system. In Phase I reactions like hydroxylation, one atom of oxygen is incorporated into the substrate, while the other forms water. NADPH acts as a reducing cofactor that donates electrons required for this reaction.

 

Statement 3: Copper deficiency can lead to anemia, neutropenia, neuropathy. This is correct. Copper is required for enzymes like ceruloplasmin and cytochrome c oxidase. Deficiency impairs iron mobilization, causing anemia, and affects bone marrow function leading to neutropenia. It also causes myeloneuropathy due to defective energy metabolism in neurons.

 

Statement 4: Tandem mass spectrometry is the gold standard for screening inborn errors of metabolism in children. This is correct. Tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) can simultaneously detect multiple amino acids, acylcarnitines, and organic acids in a single dried blood spot sample, making it the gold standard for newborn and pediatric metabolic screening programs.

questions.text: A 45-year-old homeless man comes to the emergency department due to a "pins-and-needles" sensation in his legs. He also has painful lesions on his lips and corners of his mouth. Abdominal examination reveals hepatomegaly. Laboratory evaluation shows very low urinary riboflavin excretion. Activity of which of the following enzymes is most likely directly impaired in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Succinate dehydrogenase

 

The patient shows clinical features of riboflavin (vitamin B₂) deficiency, such as angular cheilitis, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis, along with low urinary riboflavin excretion. Riboflavin is a precursor of flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) and flavin mononucleotide (FMN), both essential cofactors for various oxidative enzymes. Succinate dehydrogenase, a key enzyme in the TCA cycle and the electron transport chain (complex II), specifically requires FAD as a cofactor to oxidize succinate to fumarate. Hence, its activity is directly impaired in riboflavin deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase: Uses NADP⁺ as a cofactor, not FAD or FMN. It catalyzes the first step of the pentose phosphate pathway and is unaffected by riboflavin deficiency.

 

Option B. HMG-CoA reductase: Catalyzes the rate-limiting step in cholesterol synthesis and requires NADPH, not FAD or FMN, for its reductive biosynthetic function.

 

Option C. Isocitrate dehydrogenase: Requires NAD⁺ or NADP⁺ as cofactors, not flavin derivatives. It catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of isocitrate to α-ketoglutarate in the TCA cycle.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of base excision repair in order:

 

  1. Endonuclease excises the sugar backbone
  2. Glycosylase removes the altered base
  3. DNA-polymerase adds a nucleotide
  4. Creation of apurinic/apyrimidinic site
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2 → 4 → 1 → 3

 

In base excision repair (BER), the sequence of events begins with recognition and removal of the damaged base.

 

First, a DNA glycosylase removes the altered base (step 2), creating an apurinic/apyrimidinic (AP) site (step 4). 

 

Next, an endonuclease (specifically AP endonuclease) cuts the sugar-phosphate backbone at the AP site (step 1). 

 

Finally, DNA polymerase fills in the missing nucleotide (step 3), and DNA ligase seals the nick to complete repair.

questions.text: All of the following reactions may be inhibited in an alcoholic except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lactic acid production

 

In alcoholism, lactic acid production is not inhibited; in fact, it is enhanced. Alcohol metabolism increases the NADH/NAD⁺ ratio in the liver due to oxidation of ethanol by alcohol dehydrogenase and acetaldehyde dehydrogenase. The excess NADH shifts pyruvate toward lactate formation (via lactate dehydrogenase), leading to lactic acidosis. Therefore, lactic acid production continues or even increases, making this the exception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycolysis: Inhibited indirectly because the high NADH levels slow the conversion of glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate to 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate, thus impairing energy metabolism in hepatocytes.

 

Option B. TCA: Inhibited because high NADH inhibits key dehydrogenases (isocitrate, α-ketoglutarate, and malate dehydrogenase), reducing TCA cycle activity.

 

Option D. Fatty acid oxidation: Inhibited as the increased NADH/NAD⁺ ratio suppresses β-oxidation, leading to fatty acid accumulation and hepatic steatosis (fatty liver).

questions.text:
You are expected to produce a protein of interest. Arrange the following steps in a sequence.

 

  1. Lysis of bacterial cell
  2. Incorporating gene of interest into bacteria
  3. SDS-PAGE
  4. Hybridization
  5. Protein elution/extraction
  6. Expression of protein
questions.solution:
Ans. D) b-f-a-c-d-e

 

  • The correct sequence for producing a protein of interest begins with inserting the gene of interest into bacteria (b) using a suitable expression vector. 
  • Once inside, the bacteria express the protein (f) through transcription and translation. 
  • After sufficient expression, the bacterial cells are lysed (a) to release the intracellular protein.
  • The protein is then analyzed using SDS-PAGE (c) to check its molecular weight and purity. 
  • Next, hybridization (d) or immunodetection confirms the identity of the protein. 
  • Finally, the protein is eluted or extracted (e) for purification and further use.

H1 histone does not contribute to formation of nucleosome
Histones are rich in arginine and lysine

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about histones?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mitochondrial DNA has histone proteins

 

This statement is incorrect. Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) resembles prokaryotic DNA — it is circular and lacks histones. Instead of histone proteins, mtDNA is associated with non-histone DNA-binding proteins that help in packaging and maintenance. Thus, mitochondria do not use histones for DNA organization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histones are synthesized during S phase of the cell cycle: Correct. Histone synthesis is tightly coupled with DNA replication in the S phase to ensure proper nucleosome assembly on newly replicated DNA strands.

 

Option B. H1 histone does not contribute to formation of nucleosome: Correct. H1 is a linker histone that binds to the DNA between nucleosomes, helping in higher-order chromatin compaction, but it is not part of the nucleosomal core (which consists of H2A, H2B, H3, and H4).

 

Option D. Histones are rich in arginine and lysine: Correct. These basic amino acids confer a positive charge to histones, allowing strong electrostatic interaction with the negatively charged phosphate backbone of DNA.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect pair of UV absorption wavelength with respective compound:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Porphyrins - 200 nm 

 

This statement is incorrect. Porphyrins have a characteristic strong absorption peak, known as the Soret band, around 400–410 nm, not 200 nm. The 200 nm region corresponds mainly to peptide bond absorption in proteins. Hence, the given wavelength for porphyrins is wrong.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Tryptophan - 280 nm: Correct.Aromatic amino acids such as tryptophan and tyrosine absorb strongly at 280 nm due to their indole and phenolic ring structures, commonly used to estimate protein concentration.

 

Option B. Nucleic acids - 260 nm (N-bases): Correct. Nucleic acids absorb maximally at 260 nm due to conjugated double bonds in nitrogenous bases (adenine, guanine, cytosine, thymine, uracil).

 

Option C. NADH/NADPH - 340 nm: Correct.The reduced forms of NAD and NADP absorb at 340 nm, allowing spectrophotometric assays to monitor enzyme reactions involving NADH/NADPH formation or utilization.
